description.narrative: The overall objective of the project is to enhance prosperity of cassava smallholder farmers through increasingly profitable links to agri-business and markets.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
Output 1: Cassava smallholder farmers’ productivity increased through the adoption of practical measures Indicator 1.1. Percentage of farmers who receives training or advice on improved technology or production Indicator 1.2. Percentage of farmers access to mechanization services Indicator 1.3. Adoption rate of production and postharvest technologies
Output 2: Supply chain reliability reinforced through inclusive contract farming and new product development Indicator 2.1 Percentage of smallholder farmers’ groups reported improved capacity improved Indicator 2.2 Number of contract farming arrangement signed between Green Leader and farmers
Output 3: Capacity of National institutions, SNAs, and local agents are improved to design, lead and facilitate local cassava value chain development Indicator 3.1 Percentage of farmers access and use the Business to Business Information Platform on a regular basis Indicator 3.2 Frequency of new and updated research, information and knowledge on Value Chain development is disseminated (Low/Medium/High)

comment.narrative:
1.1 100 farmers are trained on cassava sustainable production. Two demo farms are concluded.
1.2. Contract farming is signed off between a starch factory and farmers
1.3. The national cassava policy is approved

1.1 270 farmers are trained on cassava sustainable production and 180 farmers received 3 packs of cassava fertilizers, especially those having yield decline in the past years. Two demonstration farms was completed which its result is satisfactorily with 150 to 200 percent yield increase respectively. Many farmers in demo farm areas have replicated introduced techniques.
1.2 no progress (Contract farming could not roll out due to the incomplete civil work of the starch factory)
1.3 The National Cassava policy was approved by the Royal Government of Cambodia. One short cut road as advocated by the project was ground breaking in 2020 and its construction is on-going. More development projects are targeting cassava as a potential crop for livelihood improvement and a source of agro-industrial development. Those projects include ADB, World Bank, GIZ and CAVAC

1.1 100 farmers are trained using on-farm-demonstration modality on sustainable practice on cassava production and clean cassava stems
1.2. 5% (no progress made to set target for this indicator for the year 2019)
1.3. TBC (no progress made to set target for this indicator for the year 2019)
2.1 100 farmers and relevant actors trained on engagement in contract farming (product quality control and enhancing their capacity to work under the form of farmers’ cooperative)
2.2 Number of farmers having interest in contract farming identified
3.1. 0% (no progress made to set target for this indicator as the project just started in Q4 2018)
3.2. Low (no progress made to set target for this indicator as the project just started in Q4 2018)

In 2019, the project was significantly scaled down due to lack of fund. The main donor from private sector sold the starch processing factory and could not honor the commitment with UNDP. Nonetheless, the project with UNDP fund made progress to the following. The Cassava smallholder farmers’ productivity increased through the adoption of practical measures. Two demo farms on sustainable cassava production were established in the project’s target areas. A demo on rapid multiplication of clean planting materials was set up in a safe zone where risks of disease infection are low. 178 farmers received fertilizer from the project for trials, in addition to the adoption of sustainable practices to boost cassava productivity. The capacity of national institutions, Sub National Administrations (SNAs), and local agents were improved to lead and facilitate cassava value chain development through a set of capacity development activities and engagement of all key actors in the Cassava sector, including General Department of Agriculture (GDA), Department of Agro Industry (DAI), Provincial Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (PDAFF), Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF), SNA, and Ministry of Commerce (MoC). The training included a contract farming model suited to Cassava, facilitation capacity to coordinate dialogue between farmers and the private sector, situation analysis, policy formulation, and policy advocacy. UNDP also contributed to policy dialogues in the cassava sector. The report titled Making the Case for Investment in Cassava offers evidence-based policy choices for government to prioritize investment in the Cassava sector. The report is serving as a crucial input to the development of the Cassava Sector Policy, which is currently in draft stage.
